In the U.S., there are approximately 150 million workers. That translates to 150 million taxpayers out of a population of 290 million people.
 
 The U.S. government (does not include state and local governments) pays about 350 billion dollars a year on the interest on the debt. That translates to an average of over $2,300 per taxpayer per year.
 
 If there was no debt or if the debt was much, much smaller, every taxpayer in America would have an extra $2,300, on average, in their pocket to spend every year. One would think this "extra" money would help the economy quite a bit, far more than a one-time $300 "buy your vote" tax relief.
 
 Now the average American taxpayer should wonder where is this money going since it is clearly not in their hands? Better yet, what are the voting patterns of the people who benefit from this money? The more people understand the significance of the second question, the more they will understand why certain parties are not interested in fixing the deficit, much less the debt (other than providing lip service to win elections).
 
 Instead, we have people trying to increase the debt to keep up with inflation. The only way to decrease the debt is to have a "surplus" -- so, in reality, there is never a "surplus" as long as the debt exists. To ensure that the debt keeps growing to keep up with inflation, there must be a deficit.
 
 It is like a bank account. If you were living off the interest, you would want the money in your account to keep growing at a rate that is equal to (or better yet faster) than the inflation rate. Otherwise, the money from interest would eventually be not enough to pay the bills. So additional money needs to be added into the bank account. This is no different from the debt.
